Detailed Description

Utility functions that are system/OS dependent.

Function Documentation

void dumpProcessInfo (   ) 
 

Dump process info.

Dump all available process info, used when we're about to exit due to a fatal error such as failure to allocate memory, etc. Should *not* allocate anything on the heap and *not* put anything on the stack! Print/dumps nothing if not supported.

Referenced by ISABThreadGroup::uncaughtException().

void getBacktrace (  vector< MC2String > &  bt  ) 
 

Gets the back trace.

At least on linux.

Referenced by MC2Exception::MC2Exception().

uint32 getProcessDataSize (   ) 
 

Returns process data size (data + stack).

Returns:
size in 1024 byte blocks (0 if not supported)

uint32 getProcessResidentSize (   ) 
 

Returns process resident size (data/code/etc of the process currently in memory).

Returns:
size in 1024 byte blocks (0 if not supported)

uint32 getProcessTotalSize (   ) 
 

Returns process total size (code + stack + data etc).

Returns:
size in 1024 byte blocks (0 if not supported)

void ignorePipe (   ) 
 

Ignores pipe signals that would halt the program if the connection is closed.

Now read returns -1 instead. Has no effect in MSC.

Referenced by SysUtility::IgnorePipe::IgnorePipe().

void printBacktrace (   ) 
 

Prints backtrace.

At least on linux.

void printHeapStatus (  std::ostream &  os  ) 
 

Prints information about the heap.

Used for diagnosing memory problems such as fragmentation and leaks.

void setChangePipeSignal (  bool  on  ) 
 

Sets if ignorePipe and setPipeDefault should do anything or not.

void setPipeDefault (   ) 
 

Sets the default signal handler for SIGPIPE.

Has no effect in MSC.

Referenced by TCPSocket::readMaxBytes(), and SysUtility::IgnorePipe::~IgnorePipe().

void setPriority (  uint32  newPrio  ) 
 

Attempts to increase the nice value of the current process to the newPrio nice value.

The function does not even attempt to set a negative priority even if requested.

Parameters:
newPrio The requested new priority.
